translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Tuvataka Sutta
“I ask you, kinsman of the sun,
The highest state of seclusion and peace;
Having seen what does a monk become extinguished,
Not clinging to anything in the world?”
“The root of the proliferation of mental fabrication,
(said the Blessed One)
I have cut off all ‘I am’ conceit;
Whatever craving there is in the heart,
Always train in the overcoming of that.
Whatever things one may know,
Either internally or externally;
One should not be conceited by that,

original: Na hi sā nibbuti sataṁ vuttā.
analyzed: na hi sā nibbuti satam vuttā
translated: For that is not said to be the highest state.
One should not think oneself better,

analyzed: nīceyyaḥ atha vā api sa rikkhaḥ
translated: Or equal, or worse;
Being touched by many forms,
One should stand without conceit or discrimination.
One should seek peace only internally,
Not from another, O monk;
For one who is peaceful internally,

original: Natthi attā kuto nirattā vā.🔽Majjhe yathā samuddassa,
analyzed: natthi attā kutas nirattā vā  majjhe yathā samuddassa
translated: There is no self, how could there be anything external?🔽Just as waves do not arise
When the ocean is still,
So for one who is still, without cleaving,
A monk should not be elevated anywhere.”
“The one who is not attached, with eyes open,
Who has seen the Dhamma, who has overcome the danger,
Please tell me the practice, good sir,
The Pāṭimokkha or else concentration.”
“One should not be fickle with the eyes,
One should block the ears to talk of the village;
One should not be greedy for tastes,
And one should not be attached to anything in the world.
When touched by contact,
A monk should not lament anywhere;
One should not delight in existence,
And one should not be agitated by the fearful.
With regard to food and drink,

original: Khādanīyānaṁ athopi vatthānaṁ;🔽Laddhā na sannidhiṁ kayirā,
translated: Edible foods and also clothes;🔽Having obtained them, one should not hoard,

original: Na ca parittase tāni alabhamāno.🔽Jhāyī na pādalolassa,
analyzed: na ca parittase tāni a labhamānaḥ  na pāda lolassa
translated: And not be stingy with them when not obtained.🔽A meditator should not be fickle in his steps,
One should abstain, be conscientious, and not be heedless;
Then in seats and beds,
A monk should dwell in quiet places.
One should not indulge in sleep,
But should associate with energy;
Sloth, deceit, laughter, play,
And sexual intercourse with adornments one should abandon.
Divination, dreams, and signs,
No fire-worship, no astrology,

original: Virutañca gabbhakaraṇaṁ,🔽Tikicchaṁ māmako na seveyya.🔽Nindāya nappavedheyya,
analyzed: virutam ca gabbhakaraṇa  tikiccham māmakaḥ na seveyya  nindāya na ppavedheyya
translated: No omens, no birth horoscope,🔽No reliance on medicine or a priest.🔽He should not be swayed by criticism,

original: Na uṇṇameyya pasaṁsito bhikkhu;🔽Lobhaṁ saha macchariyena,
analyzed: na uṇṇameyya pasasitaḥ bhikkhu  lobham saha mad śariyena
translated: Nor puffed up by praise;🔽He should shake off greed and stinginess,

analyzed: kodham pesuṇiyam ca panudeyya  kaya vikkaye na tiṭṭheyya
translated: And get rid of anger and slander.🔽He should not engage in buying and selling,
Nor accuse anyone of an offense;
He should not be quarrelsome in the village,

original: Lābhakamyā janaṁ na lapayeyya.🔽Na ca katthitā siyā bhikkhu,
analyzed: lābha kamyā janam na lapayeyya  na ca katthitā siyā bhikkhu
translated: Nor flatter people for personal gain.🔽He should not be a gossip,
Nor speak words that are unbeneficial;

original: Pāgabbhiyaṁ na sikkheyya,🔽Kathaṁ viggāhikaṁ na kathayeyya.🔽Mosavajje na nīyetha,
analyzed: pāgabbhiyam na sikkheyya  katham viggāhikam na kathayeyya  mosavajje na nīyetha
translated: He should not train in being overbearing,🔽Nor speak divisive words.🔽He should not be led into false accusations,
Mindful, he should not act deceitfully;
Then, with wisdom and with life,
He should not think himself superior in virtue and restraint.
Having heard much harsh speech
From ascetics and ordinary people,
He should not respond with harshness,
For the peaceful do not retaliate.
Having understood this teaching,
A monk should always train with mindfulness,
Knowing the peace called ‘stillness,’
He should not be heedless in the teaching of Gotama.
For he is the conqueror, the unconquered,
The one who has seen the truth, the one who is free from conceit;
Therefore, in the Dispensation of that Blessed One,
Being heedful, one should always train with reverence.”
The Fourteenth Portion on Tuvaṭaka is finished.
